body:
It sounds like the host you're connecting to does not match the hostname in your certificate. For gRPC Python/Node clients, if the hostnames don't match you will need to specify the `grpc.ssl_target_name_override` override (this should only be used in tests), as in the Python interop client [here](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/abbfd89dfc7e140fb1658f671b36e3276bfc37ce/src/python/grpcio_tests/tests/interop/client.py#L104). gRPC Go has its own mechanism for this, as seen in the Go [interop client](https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/blob/ef2b8e2f53fcd6654d12966394462f84e0f04066/interop/client/client.go#L55).

If this doesn't explain the issue, can you provide a repro case, or at least the code you're using for gRPC Python and Go clients, as well as the Go server code? Thanks

I have the exact same issue.
I'm working with hyperledger fabric (blockchain technology) and their `fabric-sdk-py` tools for making call to the ledger thanks to gRPC.
`fabric-sdk-py` tool has e2e tests that works fine with their provided certificates.
I tried creating my own certificate to see if it was the common name of the cert or something else that make it fails but I cannot understand why it fail.
Here is the provided cert working:
```
Certificate:
    Data:
        Version: 3 (0x2)
        Serial Number:
            0d:a0:09:c4:56:2d:d3:c2:c3:90:5a:b4:86:b8:a3:2c
    Signature Algorithm: ecdsa-with-SHA256
        Issuer: C = US, ST = California, L = San Francisco, O = org1.example.com, CN = tlsca.org1.example.com
        Validity
            Not Before: Oct 19 03:48:00 2018 GMT
            Not After : Oct 16 03:48:00 2028 GMT
        Subject: C = US, ST = California, L = San Francisco, O = org1.example.com, CN = tlsca.org1.example.com
        Subject Public Key Info:
            Public Key Algorithm: id-ecPublicKey
                Public-Key: (256 bit)
                pub:
                    04:fd:a9:24:e1:55:ab:3a:3d:ba:02:1f:49:a3:b2:
                    30:3b:ba:b5:6f:d2:e8:41:a0:79:91:99:60:70:4c:
                    70:84:07:e3:f6:3b:de:cc:26:da:b0:6c:8d:de:3f:
                    a3:c0:d8:77:48:0c:41:c0:c3:7f:76:ba:e1:e4:fb:
                    06:bd:7c:87:f7
                ASN1 OID: prime256v1
                NIST CURVE: P-256
        X509v3 extensions:
            X509v3 Key Usage: critical
                Digital Signature, Key Encipherment, Certificate Sign, CRL Sign
            X509v3 Extended Key Usage: 
                Any Extended Key Usage
            X509v3 Basic Constraints: critical
                CA:TRUE
            X509v3 Subject Key Identifier: 
                BA:42:69:37:E5:F4:90:88:22:FC:CA:C9:9B:CF:D4:E4:8B:54:B1:78:AD:DF:08:E7:08:7C:6C:AC:39:9E:BF:89
    Signature Algorithm: ecdsa-with-SHA256
         30:45:02:21:00:fe:11:ee:20:34:09:7f:f7:66:6f:b7:bc:f8:
         bf:7f:60:7b:64:e9:a8:00:8c:64:56:df:4b:02:2f:4a:0f:25:
         bf:02:20:02:67:11:91:c9:60:24:f0:27:57:de:ad:af:9f:44:
         f4:33:66:ac:ed:64:1b:01:22:82:d2:fb:ef:8e:3c:7e:d4
```
Here is the cert I manually create for testing purposes.
```
Certificate:
    Data:
        Version: 3 (0x2)
        Serial Number:
            ea:db:92:96:c3:41:56:62
    Signature Algorithm: ecdsa-with-SHA256
        Issuer: C = US, ST = California, L = San Francisco, O = org1.example.com, CN = tlsca.org1.example.com
        Validity
            Not Before: Feb  6 10:17:35 2019 GMT
            Not After : Feb  3 10:17:35 2029 GMT
        Subject: C = US, ST = California, L = San Francisco, O = org1.example.com, CN = tlsca.org1.example.com
        Subject Public Key Info:
            Public Key Algorithm: id-ecPublicKey
                Public-Key: (256 bit)
                pub:
                    04:e3:3c:9f:c3:66:55:4e:22:c4:30:95:e9:6d:d2:
                    16:19:b2:cc:03:f2:db:5c:22:bd:bb:ed:d1:f3:2d:
                    18:34:b7:04:bc:47:c4:b4:6d:22:66:8d:e6:4e:a8:
                    54:7e:92:f1:e5:70:0a:84:20:94:29:08:be:a5:8c:
                    1d:e8:6c:46:33
                ASN1 OID: prime256v1
                NIST CURVE: P-256
        X509v3 extensions:
            X509v3 Basic Constraints: 
                CA:TRUE
            X509v3 Key Usage: 
                Digital Signature, Key Encipherment, Certificate Sign, CRL Sign
            X509v3 Extended Key Usage: 
                Any Extended Key Usage
            X509v3 Subject Key Identifier: 
                A7:47:B6:D8:B2:73:6A:D8:02:F8:BE:C1:7E:4C:3E:E1:EE:40:75:F0
    Signature Algorithm: ecdsa-with-SHA256
         30:44:02:20:16:03:0c:bb:c6:48:84:ca:ae:c4:16:ec:38:81:
         50:71:bf:72:50:dc:a1:9a:fe:f2:bc:0b:55:aa:ed:28:86:80:
         02:20:4a:b9:8e:4c:13:0c:23:66:9c:c5:24:73:e3:22:1c:3b:
         c6:49:1d:09:1c:0b:9f:94:7d:94:5f:d9:a5:70:99:bc
```
Subject and Issuer are the same.
X509v3 extensions are the same.

But we have differences in the `Serial Number`, `pub`, `Subject Key Identifier` and `Signature Algorithm`.
Using the last one I get a `ssl_transport_security.cc:1233] Handshake failed with fatal error SSL_ERROR_SSL: error:1000007d:SSL routines:OPENSSL_internal:CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED`

How could we debug that and understand how this works?

@GuillaumeCisco I believe this may be a duplicate of https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/16305. There was recently [an issue fixed in gRPC core involving local trust anchors](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/17868). Can you verify that this resolves your issue? It's too recent to be in a release, but you can grab a daily build from [here](https://packages.grpc.io/archive/2019/02/9aee1731c92c8e7c880703fc948557c70bb4fc47-f4551647-92d1-49fd-ac63-40af2f440f2c/index.xml).

Thank you @gnossen for this tip.
Very surprisingly, installing this new version of grpcio led me to a lot of new errors.
I got this one `pure Go resolver`: https://medium.com/@Alibaba_Cloud/hyperledger-fabric-deployment-on-alibaba-cloud-environment-sigsegv-problem-analysis-and-solutions-9a708313f1a4
which I still do not know how to solve except with the ugly `GODEBUG=netdns=go+1`. And very weirdly this error appears on some containers, not all...


More importantly all my python `subprocess.Popen` commands are hangings forever.
Going back to version 1.18 fixes the issue... (not for the `pure Go resolver` which broke my entire config, but it seems to be a known issue for fabric hyperledger: https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-13419).

I'm in a big dead end here.

I do not understand why the grpc code sends me a `CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED`.
The only thing I have is:
```
OSError: [Errno fail to send transaction proposal] <_Rendezvous of RPC that terminated with:
	status = StatusCode.UNAVAILABLE
	details = "Connect Failed"
	debug_error_string = "{"created":"@1549533605.346930991","description":"Failed to create subchannel","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/client_channel.cc","file_line":2261,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1549533605.346895537","description":"Pick Cancelled","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/pick_first/pick_first.cc","file_line":245,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1549533605.346818554","description":"Connect Failed","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/subchannel.cc","file_line":867,"grpc_status":14,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1549533605.346633641","description":"Handshake failed","file":"src/core/lib/security/transport/security_handshaker.cc","file_line":257,"tsi_code":10,"tsi_error":"TSI_PROTOCOL_FAILURE"}]}]}]}"
```
I tried looking at the c++ code of grpc for understanding what is going on, but without success.
Right now I cannot use grpcio 1.19 and I have no information why the certificate verification fails :/

I've just succeeded making my network works without `CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED`
All was about config in hyperledger `fabric` and `fabric-ca`

Along this journey I understdood a lot of things about grpc. Especially grpc 1.19 can break a lot of things regarding the `pure Go resolver` and the `cGo resolver`.

Maybe my experience will raise information about `subprocess.Popen` python calls hanging with grpc 1.9 :)

@GuillaumeCisco, can you please open an issue in [grpc-go](https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/issues) repo regarding the pure Go and cGo resolver issues you are facing. gRPC 1.9 is really old. Please try with latest release and see if you are still facing the same issue.

@GuillaumeCisco Thank you for the tip on the hanging calls to `subprocess.Popen`. I was able to verify this behavior on master and I was able to verify that it was *not* present in `1.18`. I've [filed an issue](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/17986) if you care to follow it.

@GuillaumeCisco As a temporary workaround while the fix for the root cause of the hang is under review, running with the environment variable `GRPC_ENABLE_FORK_SUPPORT=0` will disable the core prefork handler that seems to be causing the problem.
@FabioDominio @GuillaumeCisco Can you give it another go with [1.19.0rc1](https://pypi.org/project/grpcio/1.19.0rc1/)?
@gnossen I can confirm python `subprocess.Popen` works correctly with `1.19.0rc1`
